Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Hazard Response Mitigation Systems Using High Strength and Damping Capacity Shape Memory Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Designing structures to withstand dynamic natural hazards such as earthquakes, strong winds, and hurricanes is of primary concern for civil engineers. Recent advances in architectural forms, structural systems, and high performance materials have enabled the design of very slender and lightweight structures. These flexible structures are susceptible to high levels of vibrations under strong winds and earthquakes, which may lead to structural damage and potential failure. This research project will explore the design and characterization of high performance smart alloys in multi-hazard response mitigation systems. The use of smart alloys in a novel passive control device will provide enhanced dynamic performance of buildings under various hazards of varying magnitudes. This will lead to reductions in disaster losses and in social and economic disruptions associated with future natural hazard events. With its interdisciplinary nature, this research will be closely integrated with educational plans to foster a natural process of learning and discovery.

The research objective of this project is to design, fabricate and characterize superelastic shape memory alloys with high strength and damping capacity to mitigate damage and enhance post-event functionality of mid-rise to tall steel buildings subjected to multiple hazards by implementing a novel passive structural control device. Using the Nickel-Titanium-Hafnium-Palladium (NiTiHfPd) alloys that have very high strength, high dissipation/damping capacity, good cyclic stability, and a wide operating temperature range, a shape memory alloy-based re-centering damper (SMARD) will be investigated to provide damping and re-centering capabilities to buildings subjected to wind and earthquake excitations. The advantageous characteristics of the SMARD device include large and scalable force capacity, excellent re-centering ability, high damping capacity, passive nature, ability to withstand multiple levels of hazards, and need for no special maintenance or replacement through the life-cycle. The research activities include the following: (1) characterize the shape memory behavior of heat treated NiTiHfPd alloys to establish the microstructure-property relationship, (2) tailor the microstructure to obtain high strength (greater than 1.5 gigapascal) and damping capacity (greater than 30 Joules per cubic centimeter) NiTiHfPd alloys that can operate between minus 20 degrees Celsius to plus 50 degrees Celsius with stable cyclic behavior, (3) examine cyclic response of selected alloys, (4) design and fabricate a prototype of a SMARD with a force capacity of 500 kilonewtons and stroke of 300 millimeters, and (5) characterize and model the dynamic behavior of the device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant explored the design, fabrication, and characterization of superelastic shape memory alloy (SMA)-based damping systems to provide high levels of post-event functionality in buildings by minimizing damage and residual drifts. Current practice of seismic design protects occupant safety by avoiding collapse at high seismic hazards while allows significant inelastic deformations and building damages under design level earthquakes. The formation of residual drifts in buildings as a result of inelastic deformations in structural systems will result in substantial repair costs and business downtime. A particularly attractive and viable approach to reduce downtime and even achieve immediate occupancy is the incorporation of self-centering damping systems. Superelastic SMAs have frequently been considered in the development of such systems; however, the vast majority of research to date has been on small-scale wires.

This project investigated the performance of SMA alloys that have very high strength, high dissipation/damping capacity, good cyclic stability and large operating temperature for vibration control applications. In particular, superelastic response of several polycrystalline NiTiHfPd alloys were investigated systematically to reveal the effects of composition alteration and heat treatments. The uniaxial tests were conducted on superelastic SMAs in a wide range of temperature and at various loading frequencies with four different displacement amplitudes. The effects of loading rate and temperature on superelastic characteristics of NiTiHfPd SMAs were examined. The energy dissipation capacity and equivalent viscous damping of the studied alloys were computed. The design of a novel passive vibration control device by utilizing the superelastic effect of NiTiHfPd SMAs under compression was illustrated.

In addition, alternative forms of large size superelastic SMA materials were investigated for civil engineering applications. First, superelastic SMA cables were studied. The cable form of SMAs offers several advantages and can be exploited for real-world applications of SMA damping systems, which usually require large-size elements. Since SMA cables consist of multiple small-diameter wires, they inherent the performance and cost advantages of wires. In addition, they provide redundancy if one or more of individual wires are fractured.  In this project, tensile behavior of large diameter SMA cables was fully characterized. The use of SMA cables in self-centering damping systems was illustrated. Furthermore, the buckling and post-buckling behavior of large-diameter superelastic SMA bars were investigated. A comprehensive experimental program was conducted on SMA bars with a wide range of slenderness ratios. The buckling tests were performed and the detail analysis of interaction between mechanical responses and phase transformation kinematics was carried out. This study provided in-depth information on the buckling and post-buckling behavior of larger diameter SMA bars, which can help to expand their practical use both as structural and energy-absorbing elements in a variety of applications.     

The results of this project advanced the fundamental understanding on thermal treatments-microstructure-property relationship in high strength SMA alloys and buckling response of large diameter SMA bars.  The research products can foster the application of smart materials for multi-hazard protection of structures. The high damping and high strength alloys can effectively be employed not only in a wide range of civil application but also in automotive, aerospace, oil and gas industries which are in urgent need for a reliable SMA as solid state actuators and dampers. The use of smart materials in novel passive control devices as illustrated in this project can result in enhanced performance of civil structures under various hazards of varying magnitudes. This will lead to substantial reductions of disaster losses, and in social and economic disruption associated with future natural hazards.  

The project has supported one graduate student and five undergraduate students to conduct interdisciplinary research. The knowledge generated in this project was disseminated to scientific community through journal and conference publications. In addition, the PI and graduate student participated community outreach activities targeted local middle and high schools students. Through lab demonstrations and hands-on activities with smart materials the students were encouraged to consider careers in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics arena. The PI has also developed a course module on shape memory alloy materials for a graduate level course that focuses on Smart Structures.
